decision_conditions: The development to which this permission relates must be begun not later than the expiration of three years beginning with the date of the decision notice. Reason: To comply with the provisions of S.51 of the Planning & Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plans, as set out in the attached schedule which forms part of this notice. Reason: For the avoidance of doubt and in the interests of proper planning.

All new external work shall be carried out in materials that resemble, as closely as possible, in colour and texture as specified in the approved application.Reason: To safeguard the appearance of the premises and the character of the immediate area.

Following the practical completion of the development, an updated Energy Statement shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, reflecting the measures taken in practice in Be Lean, Be Clean and Be Green stages of the Energy hierarchy to reduce carbon emitted from the operation of a development and its services, as committed to in the design stage, and the amended New Development Carbon Compensation to be paid for the remaining emissions. Reason: In the interest of sustainable development and to ensure that the Local Planning Authority may be satisfied that CO2 emission reduction targets by renewable energy are met .

The approved overheating strategy shall be implemented prior to first occupation and maintained on site, including: a. Utilizing glazing with a G value of 0.37 (BS EN 410) or less b. Incorporating KERS Cool Boost system (or equivalent to provide cooled tempered air to apartments). Boosted cooling ventilation to provide a minimum of 50 l/s of cooled tempered air from each KERS unit to serve all habitable rooms in all apartments/houses. c. Opening tilt and turn windows with a number of windows fitted with a turn restrictor with a 250mm or 300mm cable to allow increased ventilation. Reason: To ensure that suitable living conditions are achieved within the development and that the buildings do not overheat

The residential unit(s) hereby permitted shall not be occupied until the play areas have been fully provided on site in accordance with the approved plans and made available for use. These facilities shall thereafter be retained and maintained for their intended purpose for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To ensure that adequate play space is provided for the recreational needs of children living within the development, in the interests of promoting healthy lifestyles and creating a child-friendly environment

a) Prior to each Building being occupied, the Owner shall provide updated accurate and verified 'as-built' design estimates of the 'Be Seen' energy performance indicators for each Reportable Unit of the development, as per the methodology outlined in the 'As-built stage' chapter / section of the GLA 'Be Seen' energy monitoring guidance (or any document that may replace it). All data and supporting evidence should be submitted to the GLA using the 'Be Seen' as-built stage reporting webform (https://www.london.gov.uk/what-wedo/planning/implementing-london-plan/london-plan-guidance-and-spgs/be-seen-energymonitoring-guidance). The owner should also confirm that suitable monitoring devices have been installed and maintained for the monitoring of the in-use energy performance indicators, as outlined in the 'In-use stage' of the GLA 'Be Seen' energy monitoring guidance document (or any document that may replace it). b) Upon completion of the first year of Occupation or following the end of the Defects Liability Period (whichever is the later) and at least for the following four years after that date, the Owner is required to provide accurate and verified annual in-use energy performance data for all relevant indicators under each Reportable Unit of the development as per the methodology outlined in the 'In-use stage' chapter / section of the GLA 'Be Seen' energy monitoring guidance document (or any document that may replace it). All data and supporting evidence should be submitted to the GLA using the 'Be Seen' in-use stage reporting webform (https://www.london.gov.uk/what-we-do/planning/implementing-londonplan/london-plan-guidance-and-spgs/be-seen-energy-monitoring-guidance). This obligation will be satisfied after the Owner has reported on all relevant indicators included in the 'In-use stage' chapter of the GLA 'Be Seen' energy monitoring guidance document (or any document that may replace it) for at least five years. c) In the event that the 'In-use stage' evidence submitted under Clause b) shows that the 'As-built stage' performance estimates derived from Clause a) have not been or are not being met, the Owner should investigate and identify the causes of underperformance and the potential mitigation measures and set these out in the relevant comment box of the 'Be Seen' in-use stage reporting webform. An action plan comprising measures identified in Clause b) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the GLA, identifying measures which would be reasonably practicable to implement and a proposed timescale for implementation. The action plan and measures approved by the GLA should be implemented by the Owner as soon as reasonably practicable.

The residential unit(s) hereby permitted shall not be occupied until the development has been carried out in full accordance with the submitted Fire Statements. The approved fire safety measures shall be implemented prior to occupation and thereafter maintained for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To ensure that appropriate fire safety measures are incorporated into the development

No development shall take place until a Piling Method Statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The Method Statement shall include:o	Details of the type of piling to be undertaken; o	The methodology by which such piling will be carried out; o	Measures to prevent and minimise the potential for damage to subsurface water or sewerage infrastructure; and o	A programme for the works.The development shall be carried out in full accordance with the approved Piling Method Statement.Reason: To protect underground water and sewerage infrastructure and to prevent pollution of the water environment

The residential unit(s) hereby approved shall not be occupied until the development has been constructed or adapted to provide sufficient airborne and structure-borne sound insulation against externally generated noise and vibration. The insulation shall ensure that:o	Internal noise levels do not exceed 35 dB LAeq,16hr (07:00-23:00) in bedrooms, living rooms, and dining rooms; o	Internal noise levels do not exceed 30 dB LAeq,8hr (23:00-07:00) in bedrooms; and o	Maximum noise levels (LAFmax) do not exceed 45 dB more than 10 times per night in bedrooms (23:00-07:00).A scheme of mitigation measures, including provision for suitable alternative ventilation where internal noise levels would otherwise exceed the above thresholds with windows open, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the occupation of any unit. The approved scheme shall be implemented in full before occupation and shall take into account the Acoustics, Ventilation and Overheating (AVO) Guidance issued by the Association of Noise Consultants (ANC) and the Institute of Acoustics (IOA).Reason: To protect the amenity of future occupiers from noise and disturbance, in accordance with relevant local and national planning policies.

No development shall take place until an acoustic report, written in line with the methodology in BS4142:2014+A1 2019, has been submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority. The report must set out the sound level generated from the mechanical plant and state the noise control measures to be employed to ensure the noise from the mechanical plant does not exceed a level of 5dB below the typical measured background noise level measured as L(A)90 15 minutes during operational hours, at the fa√ßade of the nearest or most noise affected residential property. Reason: To protect the local amenity from noise and disturbance

All Non-Road Mobile Machinery (NRMM) of net power of 37kW and up to and including 560kW used during the course of the demolition, site preparation and construction phases shall comply with the emission standards set out in chapter 7 of the GLA's supplementary planning guidance "Control of Dust and Emissions During Construction and Demolition" dated July 2014 (SPG), or subsequent guidance. Unless it complies with the standards set out in the SPG, no NRMM shall be on site, at any time, whether in use or not, without the prior written consent of the local planning authority. The developer shall keep an up to date list of all NRMM used during the demolition, site preparation and construction phases of the development on the online register at https://nrmm.london/ Reasons: In the interests of good air quality and protecting public health

Prior to commencement (including demolition, ground works, vegetation clearance) of development, a construction environmental management plan (CEMP: Biodiversity) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The CEMP (Biodiversity) shall include the following:a) Risk assessment of potentially damaging construction activities (including harm to otters).b) Identification of "biodiversity protection zones".c) Practical measures (both physical measures and sensitive working practices) to avoid or reduce impacts during construction (may be provided as a set of method statements).d) The location and timing of sensitive works to avoid harm to biodiversity features.e) The times during construction when specialist ecologists need to be present on site to oversee works.f) Responsible persons and lines of communication.g) The role and responsibilities on site of an ecological clerk of works (ECoW) or similarly competent person.h) Use of protective fences, exclusion barriers and warning signs. i) No piles of debris or sharp materials should be stored within 30 m of the Turkey Brook's banks.j)Any stored material near the brook should be fenced off to avoid otters entering the area and using the stacks of materials as shelter.k) No works should result in the illumination of the river corridor during the night. If night working is required, then lighting should be directional to prevent illumination of the river.l) Any excavations within 30 m of the water's edge should be either covered, or ramps provided over night to allow suitable egress for otters or other mammals and ensure that they do not get trapped. Any open pipework with an outside diameter of greaterthan 150 mm must be covered at the end of each work day to prevent animals entering/becoming trapped.The approved CEMP shall be adhered to and implemented throughout the construction period strictly in accordance with the approved details, unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To minimise impacts on biodiversity

Prior to the commencement of any construction activities on the site, a comprehensive Construction Logistics Management Plan (CLMP) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The CLMP shall include, but not be limited to, the following:1. Site Access and Egress:   - Proposed routes for construction vehicles.   - Measures to minimise traffic congestion and disruption.   - Details of any temporary road closures or diversions.2. Construction Traffic Management:   - Management arrangements for construction traffic, including loading/unloading areas.   - Delivery times to avoid peak traffic hours.   - Measures to ensure pedestrian and cyclist safety.3. Site Layout and Storage:   - Site layout plan showing construction zones, storage, and welfare facilities.   - Provisions for material and waste storage to reduce visual and environmental impact.   - Mitigation measures for noise, dust, and other nuisances.4. Construction Schedule:   - Sequence and duration of construction phases.   - Expected hours of work and vehicle movements per phase.5. Health and Safety:   - Compliance with health and safety regulations.   - Risk mitigation for traffic and site hazards.   - Wheel cleaning arrangements.   - Use of operators committed to best practice (e.g., FORS membership or equivalent).The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved CLMP.Reason:To ensure that construction works are managed in a way that minimises disruption to the local highway network, protects the amenity of neighbouring occupiers, ensures public safety, and promotes sustainable construction practices.

Prior to commencement of development (inclusive of demolition and site clearance), full details of a Site Waste Management Plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The Construction Waste Management Plan shall include as a minimum:(a) Target benchmarks for resource efficiency set in accordance with best practice;(b) Procedures and commitments to minimize non-hazardous construction waste at design stage. Specify waste minimisation actions relating to at least 3 waste groups and support them by appropriate monitoring of waste;(c) Procedures for minimising hazardous waste;(d) Monitoring, measuring and reporting of hazardous and non-hazardous site waste production according to the defined waste groups (according to the waste streams generated by the scope of the works);(e) Procedures and commitments to sort and divert waste from landfill in accordance with the waste hierarchy (reduce; reuse; recycle; recover) according to the defined waste groups; and(f) No less than 85% by weight or by volume of non-hazardous construction, excavation and demolition waste generated by the development has been diverted from landfill.Reason: To maximise the amount of waste diverted from landfill.

The development shall not commence until a Contamination Desk Study has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The Desk Study shall include a Preliminary Risk Assessment comprising:o	A review of all previous uses of the site; o	Identification of potential contaminants associated with those uses; o	A conceptual site model outlining potential sources, pathways, and receptors; and o	An assessment of any potentially unacceptable risks arising from contamination at the site.No development shall take place until the Local Planning Authority has confirmed in writing that the submitted Desk Study is satisfactory.Reason: To ensure that any contamination present on the site is properly identified and assessed, and to safeguard the health and safety of future occupants.

Having regard to Condition 14, should the approved Contamination Desk Study identify the need for further investigation, a Site Investigation Scheme shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme shall provide sufficient information for a detailed assessment of the risks to all receptors that may be affected, including those off-site. The results of the site investigation shall be summarised in a generic or detailed Quantitative Risk Assessment, with conclusions and recommendations for any necessary actions.Where the Risk Assessment identifies that remediation is necessary, the following shall also be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority:a) A Remedial Options Appraisal and/or Remediation Strategy detailing the proposed remediation and mitigation measures and how they will be implemented.b) Where remediation is required:i. A Verification Plan setting out the data to be collected to demonstrate that the remediation works have been completed to a satisfactory standard;ii. A Monitoring and Maintenance Plan outlining provisions for long-term monitoring of pollutant linkages, maintenance, and contingency arrangements; andiii. A Post-Completion Verification Report for each relevant phase of the development, including results of sampling and monitoring, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to occupation of that phase, demonstrating that the site meets the agreed remediation criteria.Reason: To ensure that any contamination is properly identified, treated, and made safe, thereby safeguarding the health and safety of future occupants and users of the site.

If during the development contamination that has not previously been identified or unexpected contamination is found to be present then no further development (unless otherwise agreed in writing with the Local Planning Authority) shall be carried out until the developer has submitted an updated addendum remediation strategy specifically for the previously unidentified contamination to the Local Planning Authority detailing how it shall be dealt with and obtained written approval from the Local Planning AuthorityReason: To ensure that any contamination is properly identified, treated, and made safe, thereby safeguarding the health and safety of future occupants and users of the site.

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until waste storage and recycling facilities to satisfy the future number of occupiers on site have been provided within the development, in accordance with the Enfield's Household Recycling and Waste Planning Guidance for New Developments (February 2024). Such facilities to be retained permanently thereafter.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate waste and recycling facilities in the interests of sustainability, public health, and residential amenity

Prior to the first occupation of the development, a Delivery and Servicing Plan (DSP) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The DSP shall include details of the expected frequency and timing of deliveries and servicing activities, access arrangements, vehicle types, and measures to manage and minimise impacts on the local highway network. The approved plan shall be implemented upon first occupation and adhered to thereafter.Reason: To ensure that delivery and servicing activities associated with the development are managed in a safe, efficient, and sustainable manner, minimising disruption to the local highway network, avoiding adverse impacts on highway safety, and protecting the amenity of neighbouring occupiers and land uses.

No above ground development shall take place, excluding any works of demolition, until a landscaping scheme has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme shall include, but not be limited to, the following:Above ground until a hard and soft landscaping scheme has been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The scheme shall include, but not be limited to, the following measures:a. a statement setting out the design objectives and how these will be delivered; earthworks showing existing and proposed finished levels or contours; b. means of enclosure and retaining structures; boundary treatment[s]; c. vehicle parking layouts; other vehicle and pedestrian access and circulation areas; hard surfacing materials; d. minor artefacts and structures [e.g. furniture, play equipment, refuse or other storage units, signs, etc.]; e. proposed and existing functional services above and below ground [e.g. drainage, power, communications cables, pipelines etc. indicating alignments, levels, access points, supports as relevant]; e. retained historic or other landscape features and proposals for restoration, where relevant; renewable energy installations where relevant; lighting, floodlighting and CCTV; f. water features; g. an implementation programme, [including phasing of work where relevant]. The landscaping works shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details before any part of the development is first occupied in accordance with the agreed implementation programme. The completed scheme shall be managed and/or maintained in accordance with an approved scheme of management and/or maintenance.Reason: To ensure a high-quality landscape design that enhances the visual amenity of the development, contributes to biodiversity, and provides a pleasant and functional environment for future occupiers and visitors.

No above ground development shall take place, excluding any works of demolition, until a green landscaping scheme has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme shall include, but not be limited to, the following:a. Schedules of proposed plants and trees, including native and wildlife-friendly species and large canopy trees in appropriate locations, with details of species, planting sizes, and proposed numbers/densities;b. Plans showing the retention and protection of existing trees and shrubs;c. Details of soft landscaping, including grassed areas, turf, shrubs, and herbaceous planting;d. Details of enclosures, including types, dimensions, and treatments of walls, fences, screen walls, barriers, rails, retaining walls, and hedges;e. Details of hard landscaping, including ground surfaces, kerbs, edges, paving (rigid and flexible), unit paving, street furniture, steps, and any synthetic surfaces or other landscape features;f. Explanation of how the landscaping scheme integrates with and supports the approved Drainage Strategy;g. Calculation and demonstration of the Urban Greening Factor (UGF) score in accordance with the London Plan.All landscaping works shall be carried out in full accordance with the approved details and completed during the first planting season following practical completion of the development. A management and maintenance plan shall also be submitted and approved, setting out long-term maintenance responsibilities and schedules. Any planting that dies, becomes severely damaged, or diseased within five years of completion shall be replaced with planting of the same species and size, or an approved alternative, to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.The development shall be carried out and maintained strictly in accordance with the approved details unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a high-quality landscape design that enhances the visual amenity of the development, supports biodiversity, integrates with sustainable drainage systems, and contributes to urban greening

The development hereby permitted shall ensure that:i. A minimum of 10% of the dwellings comply with Building Regulation Requirement M4(3) 'wheelchair user dwellings'; andii. All remaining dwellings comply with Building Regulation Requirement M4(2) 'accessible and adaptable dwellings'.Evidence demonstrating compliance with these requirements shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority upon request.Reason: To ensure that the development provides accessible and adaptable homes to meet the needs of all future residents, including wheelchair users.

Prior to first occupation of the development, the 1 disabled residential parking bay identified on drawing Proposed Ground Floor Plan Site A (0824-BPA-SA-00-DR-A-P1100 C) and 3 disabled residential parking bays identified on drawing Proposed Ground Floor Plan Site B (0824-BPA-SB-00-DR-A-P1110B) shall be provided on site. The spaces shall only be used for the parking of private motor vehicles for 'blue badge' residents and shall not be used for any other purpose. Such facilities to be retained permanently thereafter. Reason: To ensure the development provides adequate on site car parking for disabled residents

Prior to first occupation of the development, the 5 residential parking bay identified on drawing Proposed Ground Floor Plan Site A (0824-BPA-SA-00-DR-A-P1100 C) and 12 residential parking bays identified on drawing Proposed Ground Floor Plan Site B (0824-BPA-SB-00-DR-A-P1110B) shall be provided on site. The spaces shall only be used for the parking of private motor vehicles and shall not be used for any other purpose.   Reason: To ensure the development provides adequate on site car parking

Prior to occupation of any residential unit  a car parking management plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. This will demonstrate how the Owner will allocate, provide and manage car parking provision, which will include:a. A car park plan with clearly marked out spaces for residents, loading, unloading, visitors, accessible parking bays and parking bays for Car Clubs (as appropriate);b. Contact details (telephone number, email, name) of a person/company responsible for managing of car parking;c. Proposed parking controls to keep clear the turning areas for delivery/service vehicles;d. Proposals for management of the risk of overspill parking f. Details of parking allocation, enforcement, fees, maintenance and management; and Parking spaces should not be leased and not sold.ReasonTo ensure an appropriate level of car parking is provided for the relevant units and to understand clearly the management strategy regards parking on site, to be convenient and accessible for future residents and users.

No dwelling hereby approved shall be occupied until a scheme for the implementation of waiting restrictions (double yellow lines) around the site access points have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The waiting restrictions shall be implemented in accordance with the approved scheme and retained thereafter. Reason: To ensure safe and unobstructed access to and from the development, in the interest of highway safety and to minimise potential conflicts between vehicles and pedestrians.

Prior to first occupation of the development, the 58 cycle parking spaces identified on drawings Proposed Ground Floor Plan Site A (0824-BPA-SA-00-DR-A-P1100 C) and Proposed Ground Floor Plan Site B (0824-BPA-SB-00-DR-A-P1110B) shall be provided on site.   Reason: To ensure the development provides adequate on site car parking

a)	Prior to the commencement of the superstructure of the building,  typical details, including siting and design of plugs, of electric vehicular charging points including the design specification sheet to be provided in accordance with London Plan standards (minimum 20% of spaces to be provided with electric charging points and a further 20% passive provision for electric vehicles in the future) shall be provided to the Local Planning Authority for approval in writing.b)	All electric charging points shall be installed in accordance with the approved details prior to first occupation of the development approved and permanently maintained and retained.Reason: To ensure that the development complies with the sustainable development policy requirements of the London Plan.

Notwithstanding the submitted SUDs strategy, prior to the commencement of development (excluding demolitions works) a final SUDS strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. This shall be based on the strategy submitted but shall also identify:o	Qualityo	On site A, RWPs should be directing discharge onto the surface of permeable paving instead of the subbase to avoid siltation and ease of inspection and maintenance.o	On site B, RWPs should be directing discharge onto raingarden surfaces for the same reasons and overflow directed to the surface of permeable pavers before infiltrating.o	Functionalityo	Cross sections, sizes and specifications of the proposed SuDS features must be provided in the context of the development accompanying drawings in Appendix G.  Reason: To ensure the sustainable management of water, minimise flood risk, minimise discharge of surface water outside of the curtilage of the property and ensure that the drainage system will remain functional throughout the lifetime of the development

Prior to commencement of development (inclusive of demolition and site clearance), full details of a Whole Lifecycle Carbon Assessment shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The Whole Life Carbon Assessment shall at each of the following stages of development include as a minimum:a)        Prior to commencement of any work on site including all works of deconstruction and demolition.(b)        Prior to commencement of any construction works.(c)        Within 3 months of first occupation of the development.Where the updated assessment submitted pursuant to (a) or (b) above identifies that changes to the design, procurement or delivery of the approved development will result in an increase in embodied carbon (A1-A5) above the benchmarks established by your application stage Whole Life Carbon assessment, you must identify measures that will ensure that the additional carbon footprint of the development will be minimised.Reason: To ensure the development minimises carbon emissions throughout its whole life cycle

Prior to commencement of any construction works, a Circular Economy Statement shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details. Prior to occupation, a report shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority evidencing how the Circular Economy Goals and Commitments in the pre-construction Circular Economy Statement have been satisfied.Reason: To ensure the development is resource efficient and maintains products and materials at their highest use for as long as possible

Prior to development (notwithstanding on-site demolition) no development above slab level shall commence until a report detailing the external lighting scheme and how this will not adversely impact upon wildlife has been submitted to and approved in writing by the LPA. The report shall include the following figures and appendices:o A layout plan with beam orientationo A schedule of equipmento Measures to avoid glareo An isolux contour map showing light spillage to 1 lux.The approved lighting plan shall thereafter be implemented as agreed.Reason: To limit the impact of light pollution from artificial light on nature conservation

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until a Certificate of Compliance in accordance with Secured by Design Homes Guide 2024 (or the relevant Secure by Design Guide(s) or an achieved Crime Prevention Standard) has been submitted to, and approved in writing by, the Local Planning Authority. The approved details shall thereafter be installed and permanently retained.Reason: To ensure that the development incorporates appropriate crime prevention measures and promotes a safe and secure environment for future residents

The residential unit(s) hereby permitted shall not be occupied until the Building Regulations Optional requirement G2 for water consumption of no more than 105 litres or less per head per day (excluding allowance of up to five litres for external water consumption) has been complied with. The measures shall thereafter be permanently retained.

No development shall take place until a scheme detailing measures to ensure the development achieves air quality neutral status, in accordance with the London Plan and relevant guidance, has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme shall include measures to minimise traffic-related emissions and other pollutant sources associated with the development. The approved measures shall be fully implemented prior to occupation and retained thereafter.Reason: To minimise the impact of the development on local air quality and ensure compliance with the air quality neutral requirements

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the approved details and shall achieve an Urban Greening Factor (UGF) score of at least 0.4, unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure the development contributes to urban greening, biodiversity, and climate resilience

a)	Prior to the construction of superstructure, the following details shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.i.	Full details of biodiversity enhancements, to include plans showing locations and elevations of a minimum of bat bricks, bird boxes and insect boxes  ii.	Ecological Management Plan in respect of the planting and biodiversity enhancement measures b)	Prior to first occupation of the development, confirmation of installation of the biodiversity enhancements together with accompanying photographic evidence shall be submitted to and approved in writing, by the local planning authority.The installation shall be retained and maintained as such for the lifetime of the development.Reason: To enhance the site post development by providing suitable nesting features for birds, bats and invertebrates

Reason Compliance with Shadow Section 106 AgreementNo development shall take place on any part of the Site unless and until all parties with a (1) legal interest to the extent it may enable them to carry out any part of the development in the relevant part of the Site and (2) a legal locus to enter into a planning obligation pursuant to Section 106 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) have entered into such a planning obligation (unless otherwise agreed by the Local Planning Authority) in accordance with and substantially in the form of, the draft agreement appended to this decision notice ("Shadow S106").The Council would have refused the planning application in the absence of the section 106 agreement and at the time of this permission being issued the applicant was not able to bind the legal interests in the development site under the section 106 agreement.  Development must not commence on any part of the Site until the legal interests that are capable of being bound under the section 106 agreement are so bound and the obligations are enforceable in accordance with the aims and objectives of policies Core Policies 38 and 46 of the Enfield Core Strategy (2010) and to ensure all the terms of reference (on page 54-55 of the committee report) are met.

Compliance with S106 ObligationsNo development shall take place on any part of the Site without fully complying with all the obligations, covenants, restrictions, terms and conditions (together "Obligations") in the Shadow S106, as if the party carrying out the development was a party to a planning obligation in the same form of the Shadow S106. Provided that this condition does not apply to any part of the site that the party has an interest in and that party has entered into a planning obligation pursuant to Condition 1.
description: Redevelopment to provide 27 no. residential units (Use Class C3) alongside car parking, cycle parking, refuse and recycling storage, amenity space, playspace, landscaping and other associated works.

application_details.lead_registered_social_landlord: The Mayor and Burgesses of the London Borough of Enfield

constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: LLA Maximum height level: All buildings, structures, and works exceeding 150 metres in height (492.1 feet)

subdivision_of_building:
Proposal does not affect any buildings as existing Site are car parks. 
Proposal does not affect any buildings as existing Site are car parks.
